sub_bullets.text: Describe the principles of Lean, including continuous improvement, waste reduction, and maximizing customer value, and explain their relevance to project planning.
Recognize and classify value-adding versus non-value-adding activities, and identify the five types of waste in a project workflow.

learning_obj.text: Measure and Evaluate Lean Success with Metrics:

sub_bullets.text: Identify and utilize key Lean metrics, such as cycle time, lead time, and throughput, to measure project performance and guide decision-making for continuous improvement.
Motion – movements of people, materials, or machines are more complicated or occur more frequently than necessary
Inventory – too much stock results in loss of storage, management burden, and loss of value over time
Time – processes are interrupted or idle, causing costly delays
Overproduction
Human Potential – not utilizing the full capabilities of people

characteristics.text: Encourages teams to document effective processes

sub_bullets.text: Cost-effective, decreased resource use leading to lower prices and happier customers
Understand customer needs and values—what is the customer actually looking for?
Streamline the process to eliminate spending on things the customer won’t value
Identify and map all steps and resources involved in delivering the product or service
Similar to the 'plan' step of Agile methodology
Address potential roadblocks before starting to avoid unnecessary resource expenditure
Base production on actual customer demand to reduce overproduction and excess inventory
Continually seek ways to reduce waste and improve processes

drawbacks.text: Relies on every team buying into the principle

example.text: Amazon uses Lean management principles in its fulfillment centers

sub_bullets.text: Pick-to-Belt Process: Workers pick products from shelves and place them on conveyor belts leading to packaging areas
5S System: Workspaces are organized for maximum efficiency and safety
Kaizen: Continuous improvement approach encouraging employees to spot and eliminate waste
Just-in-Time Inventory: Minimizes inventory on hand to reduce costs and risk of obsolescence

evaluation.text: What are three benefits of using the lean methodology?
How can lean principles benefit a project of your choosing? Write it down.
